We went to Italy with our 12 and 15 year old sons and our older married sons 13 years ago. Rome:The Vatican is a must, also the Castel San Angelo. My 12 year old and I took a day trip by train to Ostia Antica. It was the highlight of his trip. (a complete Roman City in ruins).
Venice:The glass-works at Murano are touristy but interesting. You can take the water taxi to Lido and rent bikes.
Florence: At our youngest son's request we took a train from Florence to Pisa for the Leaning Tower. We combined it with a stop in Lucca. (very easy). Also, I believe the other boys visited a museum of with Galileo's inventions. Go to a soccer game.

I have been to Italy several times and suggest using trains when possible. Driving in Tuscany is fine but Rome, Florence and Naples are very difficult (and I drive in NYC) .

I do not have current information but several years ago I bought advance reservation tickets and museum passes for a son visiting Italy.

Also ,I used the book Daytrips Italy by Earl Steinbecker

Enjoy...It is a fun family friendly country!!

I have suffered from depression and found that the use of sharing via social media has been a pathway towards healing. It has also helped me recover by re-engaging with friends, new and old, community events, political rallies and more.

I am an activist for social justice, volunteer to my community, event photographer and writer. I do not care if our government knows about me. What I really want is for my friends and acquaintances – possibly future friends – to also know about me.

I primarily use facebook but have recently started to use Google Plus and Twitter. To use social media, I mean to really share your life in it, in words, pictures and video, is to reap its value - and it has so very much value. It has greatly improved the breath and stroke of my life. It has not only lifted my depressed spirits, it has enabled me to meet new people, first online and then later in person, people I would have never normally met or had access to - interesting people with engaged lives – artists, writers, activists, volunteers, musicians, politicians, scientists, business consultants and professionals in many fields.

Social media has also enabled me to stay in touch with my diaspora of far flung and out of area friends and family. As my facebook profile can be seen by anybody who has a facebook account, it has enabled former friends and contacts from earlier stages in my life to find me again.

Not all online friendships work out, however. Thankfully, there is a solution. If a facebook connection doesn't work out, I can block the person, something I have done only four times in the last two years. Once blocked, the offending person can't see me and I can't see them. Problem solved. Google+ also has a blocking feature.

My social media life has been a life enriching and healing experience. I recommend giving the act of sharing your life online a chance. The benefits are many.

David

I think that for ordinary users - that is most of us - meaning users who do not have an enormous amount of files or extremely large files, cloud storage is not really necessary. Today it's become trendy to have files in the cloud and my feeling is that a lot of people look at it as a must have. As to myself, I regularly backup files (not any file, only those that are important to me or that I want to have everywhere I am) on an optical disk as well as a USB drive with sufficient storage space. This way I have total control of my files and do not have to pay a cloud service.As for really sensitive files, like banks, financials, addresses, passwords and the like I am not yet prepared to place them in the cloud, where they might be the object of hacker attack or even curiosity of the server operator. The cloud idea is a great idea for computing (did anyone remember that the first to launch it, in the early nineties, was Larry Ellison, who does not even claim the credit for it and, boy, does he have an ego ?) but I'm not buying it until it proves to be entirely secure. And no site, today, can claim that in the Internet. With my DVD or USB drive in my pocket, or in my bank safety box, I have peace of mind.

Microsoft offers 25GB of online storage with Windows Live. However, as already noted, the sync capability seems somehow flawed. There are many other benefits including on-line versions of Word, Excel, etc.

Personally, it is hard to beat Apple's iDrive on MobilMe. Works completely transparently and leaves me with access to my documents from any computer as well as synchronized access from any of my personal PCs or Macs.

What Senator Sessions fails to state is that we already sustain a larger level of spending than we have revenues to support, hence the deficit.

For a decade now we have "forgotten" to raise sufficient revenues - found unnecessary wars to fight and added benefits to Medicare enriching pharmaceutical and insurance companies at taxpayer expense, while giving rich American's tax cuts. We also ditched regulations on banks that had served the Country well, and promoted homeownership, creating a housing bubble.

Since 2008, the bubble has burst and we've bailed out banks AIG and the automobile industry, provided aid to State governments in crisis (who unlike the Federal Government may not run deficits), extended unemployment benefits for workers who were only supposed to be temporarily unemployed, and made some politically-weakened efforts to rationalize healthcare spending and stimulate the economy. Most of this was necessary - more could have been done.

We know how to address the budget deficit. This problem was first created in the eighties, repaired in the nineties, and seriously broken then ignored in the last decade when "Deficits didn't matter." We have to go back to what we did in the nineties (along with some necessary spending now to encourage jobs). The Affordable Care Act or some tougher version of health care reform must be implemented for our long-term prosperity to be assured. There's no need to mess much with Social Security.

The Republican and Democratic spokespersons demonstrated quite nicely why the US credit rating was downgraded and why the US political system is incapable of rationally solving the nation's Economic problems. The last time the US found itself in such a economic debacle was in the Fall of 1929. Thus, far American voters and credit-rating agencies have seen nothing to indicate that this debacle will turn out any differently than Great Depression I - which is why the US got Social Security.

One thing politicians might keep in mind is that when a sufficient number of middle and lower class folks get thrown under the bus, they can get quite angry and vote in their own best interest. In 1932 FDR carried 42 states, essentially all 48 but for New England.
As an aside, it would be helpful if the author and/or the editors knew the difference between "principal" and "principle."

We know where the blame lies. Three clearly phrased questions in the latest NYT/CBS poll show the tea party's approval ratings in the tank. Worth taking a look at if you have any doubts.

Then too, in an interview with NPR this morning, the chairman of S&P's sovereign ratings committee literally pointed to Obama's deficit reduction plan as the way to go: "You're going to need eventually either some action on entitlements -- either by changing the parameters of the programs or raising additional revenues to pay for those programs." The NPR interviewer responded: "Changing the parameters of Medicare and Social Security or raising taxes. That sounds like quite a challenge for this White House. ...But it's been a challenge for President Obama since he said months ago that he wanted to do this. This was the plan that he was pushing all along during the debt ceiling talks. ..."

The GOP can gnash its teeth and try to wash its hands of any blame in the situation, but from the sovereign ratings committee on Wall Street to the farthest drought-ravaged corners of Texas, America knows where the blame lies.

From the S&P release on the downgrade:
“Compared with previous projections, our revised base case scenario now assumes that the 2001 and 2003 tax cuts, due to expire by the end of 2012, remain in place. We have changed our assumption on this because the majority of Republicans in Congress continue to resist any measure that would raise revenues, a position we believe Congress reinforced by passing the act.”

Many of America's rich people simply do not acknowledge the contribution that government spending makes to their own incomes, as in Michelle Bachman's forgotten agricultural subsidies. If they took that into account they'd realize that the government is paying at least part of their taxes for them, so their tax rates are even less than they appear.
